instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> runs on battery no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Had bad readings on ISL replaced and currently:


1-0v
2-16.58V
3-3.9V
9-0V
12-3.42V
13-3.39V
14-3.35V
15-48mV
17-0v
19-5.1V
20-5.08V
27-16.43V


resistance pins
17/18 2.9ohm
27/28 22 ohm

PPBUS g3H =0V both sides of F7140, diode on this fuse to ground .403, no short with fuse removed.

replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> - had to get them quite hot to pull from other known good board that has ram slot issues. Possible they fried moving them? Other things to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> runs on battery no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check R/<CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR> and their traces.
Also check R/C networks at pins 5, 7, 8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> runs on battery no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: CHanged out <CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR> just in case... resistors and traces/measurements seem good local to ISL at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> runs on battery no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> runs on battery no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I shorted some things replaced ISL i can't even count how many times at this point... Had a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>... solved that by replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> again. Ended up losing trace on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>. Got that. <RESISTOR>R7919</RESISTOR> has high resistance in 1.5+ Mega ohms ... can I simply just put a resistor across that or is that a tell?

I have same values as above except pin 17 and PPBUS both high:

1-0v
2-16.58V
3-3.9V
9-0V
12-3.42V
13-3.39V
14-3.35V
15-48mV
17-16.35V
19-5.1V
20-5.08V
27-16.43V


resistance pins
17/18 2.2ohm
27/28 20.1 ohm

PPBUS g3H =16.34V

Does the ISL fail easily? is it sensitive to heat? I've probably changed the ISL 5x's now. Make sure its on there to best I can square under stereo microscope. CHeck resistance readings before I give it power... but ppbus changed when I changed those parts so ISL change is doing something... keep changing til I get PPBUS? losing my mind on this one

threads.message:
changed out <CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR> one more time with same results. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> steadies at 4.1V with F7040 removed.

Actually PPBUS seems to be steady 4.1V now with F7040 placed. Replaced L7030 just in case. Checked resistance pins 17/18 and 27/28... still good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> runs on battery no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check/change all components from pins 5, 7, 8.
First be sure <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> is good; pin 6/<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> MUST have 3V!!!

threads.message:
man I"m really disliking this board...
You're right pin 6 is 1.742V...
All resistors and connections in that area are tested and good...
replaced <CAPACITOR>C7016</CAPACITOR>/15/42 from board that worked but had ram slot issues and nothing still. 
All ISL readings are the same.

threads.message:
I'm actually getting 3.51Vat pin 12 and 3.48V at 13... usually that should measures exactly 3.42, correct?

<RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> was measuring correct... replaced anyway and 1.763V at pin 6.  getting the 3.48V on backside of <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> so I see what you're saying it measures .8k so its less than the 1k my schematic says... voltage would be higher than normal.  I don't understand why I'm not getting 3v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> runs on battery no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> is good, then change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

1.7V at CELL pin is like floating air for <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
As per schematic, it will work in 1 (one) cell configuration.
This is the reason of 4V output.
